com.biomatters.geneious.publicapi.documents.sequence

Class ExternalSort<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.biomatters.geneious.publicapi.documents.sequence.ExternalSort<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of element to be sorted

    public class ExternalSort<T>
extends Object
    Sorts some objects, using temporary files on disk if necessary because the objects can't all fit in memory (e.g. sorting several gigabytes of data)

    Typical usage is to construct an ExternalSort. Call add(Object, long) to add each element. Then call get() the same number of times to get all the elements in order.

    This class assumes at least 140MB of memory is free prior to sorting, and will aim to maintain at least 70MB of free memory at all times during the sort. We use 70MB because Geneious warns about running low on memory at 50MB so we don't want to go below that. Only once free memory drops below 70MB does the ExternalSort resort to using temporary files. If free memory does not drop below this, then the sort will be performed entirely in memory.

    Since:
    API 4.40 (Geneious 5.4.0)

    • Constructor Detail

      • ExternalSort

        public ExternalSort(ExternalSort.Serializer<T> serializer,
            Comparator<T> comparator,
            ProgressListener progressListener,
            int maximumNumberOfElementsToSort)
        Parameters:
        serializer - specifies how to serialize the objects to be sorted
        comparator - for comparing the objects to be sorted.
        progressListener - a progress listener for reporting progress to and cancelling. Note that calls will be made to this progress listener as side effects of later calls on this sorter. If the progress listener requests a cancel during one of these later calls, they will throw an IOException with "Canceled" as the message. Since calls may be made later to this progress listener to avoid progress interfering with later calls, it is strongly recommended you create split progress using ProgressListener.createSplitProgress(jebl.util.ProgressListener, int)
        maximumNumberOfElementsToSort - an upper bound number of elements to be sorted, or -1 if unknown. Used only for progress reporting purposes.

    • Method Detail

      • setReturnElementsTwice

        public void setReturnElementsTwice()
        Flags this sorter to return all the elements twice. (i.e. after get() has been called once per element, get() may be called that many times again retrieve all the elements again.
        Since:
        API 4.43 (Geneious 5.4.3)

      • add

        public void add(T element,
       long upperBoundOnMemoryRequiredByElement)
         throws IOException
        Adds a new element to sort
        Parameters:
        element - the new element
        upperBoundOnMemoryRequiredByElement - an upper bounds on the memory used by this object and any other data stored in memory since the previous call to this method. This estimate is used to determine how frequently to check free memory and resort to sorting on disk.
        Throws:
        IOException - if there is a problem writing to disk.

      • cleanup

        public void cleanup()
             throws IOException
        If the calling code decides not to call get() for all sequences added, then it should call this method to close and delete all temporary files. Normally, get() automatically cleans up temporary files when they are done with.
        Throws:
        IOException - if files can't be closed or deleted

      • isAllInMemory

        public boolean isAllInMemory()
                      throws IOException
        Returns true if all this data is in memory (i.e. not flushed to disk). This may only be called after adding all sequences. A side effect of this method is to flush the final block (or all data if running low on memory) to disk if necessary.
        Returns:
        true if all this data is in memory (i.e. not flushed to disk)
        Throws:
        IOException - if we can't flush the final block to disk if necessary

      • get

        public T get()
      throws IOException
        Gets the next sorted element
        Returns:
        the next sorted element
        Throws:
        IOException - if there is a problem reading from disk
